body: I am going to work on this.  I will let you know if I run into any problems.
I am not sure I am ready for this ticket, so I am going to work on something else.

After looking further into this they "whys" of how things are being done in MINI vs STANDALONE are too unclear - why can't STANDALONE create users the same way as MINI vs adding them to the config file?
Therefore I recommend deleting this ticket and leaving it up to resolutions made in ticket #1074

Ok, that's what I suspected might be the case. Thanks for the info.

You think the XSD location change is still good to make? I would've erred on the side of changing none of them after your original message.

Yeah, updating the XSD location is good... it's used as a hint to XML processing tools to download the schema from that location if it doesn't already have a copy locally for that namespace (many IDEs ship with some schemas for well-known namespaces already). If the URL changes, because the website goes HTTPS only, or if we just want to provide a more secure source where the schema can be downloaded from, it's good to change that.

How about f244d9e, @ctubbsii ?

(need to remember to apply to 1.9 and merge up ;))

It looks like the class that needs to be updated is AccumuloClusterPropertyConfiguration.  Possibly throwing exceptions with additional info instead of just logging the exception.  However, I am not sure how to test this.  Is this part of the 'mvn verify' goal, or is there another way to test?  I was reading about 'mvn verify' but even if that does test this class, I am not sure how to create the error condition with the properties file so it shows my updates in the test.

Any info would be appreciated.  Thanks.

This seems very doable but I am not familiar enough with the code architecture, what services are implemented where and what defines a service in this case vs. a property that has a classname for a value.  Relinquished to one more seasoned.
I can take a look at this and try to determine if it is all covered.

TransportCachingIT used to hang indefinitely before we added a timeout to it to force it to be killed if it took too long. It's quite possible there's a concurrency bug in there somewhere, but I'm not familiar with that code.

> Is this a straight forward as setting the below and removing the synchronized blocks?

I looked at the code and I think more may be required.  There is a thread that closes idle unreserved connections.  Would need to ensure there are no race conditions with this code and reserving a connection.  That is one example where removing the sync may introduce race conditions.
Merged in 87d48ef2f5f54f3b8e675332ebe60d3a75b1bed3

I understand that and I am pretty sure I know where to update the code.  What I don't understand is what is the command that uses these arguments:

"-Dit.test=AccumuloClientIT -Dtest=foo -Daccumulo.it.properties=/path/to/accumulo-it.properties"

I have been reviewing the docs on MAC but I don't see any place where these arguments are described or used in any example.  If you could provide an example or point me to some docs I have not found, I would appreciate it.

Thanks.

The testing.md file in the standalone instance section has some useful info on how to configure and how to run the test. Link provided. 

https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/master/TESTING.md

Let me know if you have any additional questions.

If I understand your question, those are being passed to maven / test plugins (failsafe / surefire) and to the test frameworks. Maybe the documentation at https://maven.apache.org/surefire/maven-failsafe-plugin/ helps?

 

-Dit.test= AccumuloClientIT  specifies to the plug in what IT test to run.

-Dtest=foo – passes a fake unit test so no unit tests actually get executed.

 

Not sure without looking what’s in the accumulo-it.properties.

"-Dit.test=AccumuloClientIT -Dtest=foo -Daccumulo.it.properties=/path/to/accumulo-it.properties"

I have been reviewing the docs on MAC but I don't see any place where these arguments are described or used in any example. If you could provide an example or point me to some docs I have not found, I would appreciate it.

Thanks.

Sorry for the wall of text, but I wanted to provide you with additional background and some of my thoughts.  

This is related to https://github.com/apache/accumulo/pull/1172, which both I and Christopher have been working.  Removing the legacy metrics looks like it will also allow upgrading apache commons config too, so that makes this a blocker for 2.0, so any help is very welcome.

Christopher identified a couple of additional files that I particularly wanted to check that there was some kind of hadoop2 metrics equivalent - anything that extended AbstractMetricsImpl and especially the ThriftMetrics. You can look at the pull request 1172 and see which files seemed to be unused if the legacy code path is eliminated that we have identified so far.

If they are not currently covered, then we should be able to add equivalent hadoop2 metrics as replacements (probably as a separate issue / pull request), but something likely very desirable for releasing 2.0.

It may not be an exact match - I actually have some questions / reservations of the underlying calculations used in the legacy metrics - the way of calculating rolling averages and some others are not familiar to me and I cannot find any references, but they seem that they could be optimizations / light-weight methods for approximating those calculations.  If we "replace" them with standard hadoop2 metrics or something from apache math, then a review of the calculation weight vs code paths should be reviewed so as not to impact performance.  An example (and not implying that we would) but there are ways to calculate standard deviation in one pass vs the naive methods that keeps the samples and uses two passes, or otherwise suffer from stability problems. 

Slight differences should not be a show stopper if we document the differences as well as explain the "upgraded" calculations. Another option would be to pull those calculation methods forward. but report them through hadoop2 metrics. My personal preference is for something standard that is backed by experts in numerical calculations as long as everything else is equal.

From a quick look, the hadoop2 metrics seem well thought out and efficiently implemented, and they are likely okay, but there could have been hadoop assumptions that may make them less than ideal for specific circumstances. 

If we can get these issues examined and documented, then that will really clear the path for this for 2.0.

These items were not used in the code at all, and should not have been required for compilation error marker occurred in the editor on the first line of the file. Again, this class had no compile-time references to this class is only used within the runtime library. Read more: BigData Hadoop Training in Delhi

I talked to several users, and as far as I can tell, nobody is using the legacy metrics. So, if there is a gap in what the two implementations provide, it doesn't seem to be of significance to at least those users I interviewed. I think we can probably close this, and selectively add new metrics as needed.
@cjmctague I am removing the 2.0 label for this PR.  If you want to make these changes for 2.1 that may be more appropriate.

> mvn clean verify -Dfailsafe.groups=org.apache.accumulo.test.categories.MiniClusterOnlyTests

This will run all the Tests and all the verification plugin checks, which will take a while.  I'd recommend running just a clean without any tests which should only take a few minutes.  Do that with this command:
`mvn clean verify -DskipTests -Dspotbugs.skip`

I looked at one of the classes that I was concerned about (AbstractMetricsImpl) there is a metrics2 implementation and the calculations that it are doing are documents.  There synchronization in the method chain that we call, but being that it has been being used without reported issues I'm less concerned that it represents a significant performance hit.
The call chain ends up create a metrics2 SampleStat that generates equivalent status to the AbstractMetricsImpl and does not generate the extended metrics like stddev,... that are available with metrics2 - if those are needed by users the can generate them using the "raw" number that are being reported.
I agree with closing this.

I may be able to use the `PropertiesConfigurationLayout` directly in some places to read/write the properties files instead of the `FileBasedConfigurationBuilder`. Doing so may help avoid the extra optional dependency on commons-beanutils. However, I'm not sure if it will have the same property interpolation features, so I'd need to check that first.

Two other things that I should do before merging: check LICENSE/NOTICE change implications for the updated dependencies, and possibly remove the custom `GENERAL_DYNAMIC_CLASSPATHS` property interpolation feature, which isn't really needed.

I am comfortable with the changes to RangePartitioner @ctubbsii.  I tested the hdfs caching mechanism using the "fragment" after a hash tag in the URI when adding to hdfs cache.  I verified proper caching in the debugger of the Intellij while stepping through the BulkIngestExample.java class during execution.  The main function of the BulkIngestExample class calls RangePartitioner.setSplitFile which calls job.addCacheFile the URI with the fragment. The during the actual MR job execution ,  in RangePartitioner.getCutPoints ,  the splits.txt file is access by the fragement URI called: org.apache.accumulo.hadoop.mapreduce.partition.RangePartitioner.cutFile  in the present working directory of the script or project.  This was my last concern about the code changes and I am confident it is ready for merging.   

Let me know if there is anything that you feel I have missed here.
Thanks @keith-turner , will do that.
I performed Continuous Ingest verify from the accumulo-testing repository to confirm that MapReduce works fine with this class path change.

@hkeebler The https://github.com/apache/accumulo-proxy repository was created to take what we have in https://github.com/apache/accumulo/tree/master/proxy and separate it into its own (sub-)project within the Accumulo community. I started the work, but did not finish. The goal is to delete it from the main Accumulo builds, so it can live (or die) on its own. I'm not sure what is needed to finish it, but ideally, it should have all the latest updates from https://github.com/apache/accumulo/tree/master/proxy (so that can be deleted) and it should build against the latest Accumulo 2.0 SNAPSHOT (eventually 2.0 proper when that is released).

The task here should be to delete the proxy/ module.
The task in https://github.com/apache/accumulo-proxy/issues should be to ensure it builds and works over there.

> I remember chatting with somebody about creating something like a UtilityContext for the various server-side utilities, for the same reason. Do you think the Initialize command is sufficiently distinct that it needs its own, or do you think it could use a more general UtilityContext?

I am not sure.  I would hate to have too many Context objects, that would be confusing.  The nice thing about having an IntializedContext is that it would capture the state only during the initialize process.  Having a UtilityContext seems a little too broad.  Perhaps a "ServerUtilContext" would be better in at least you know where the context is coming from.  But that just seems like what ServerContext would do.  What else would a UtilityContext object handle differently than ServerContext?

I was definitely thinking just a "ServerUtilContext", not a more general utility context. The main thing is that, unlike the ClientContext, it would assume access to the server-side configuration, but unlike the ServerContext, it wouldn't do things that are needed for server's only (crypto service, unique name allocator, etc.).

It's probably best to start with just an InitializeContext, and not worry about a general purpose one unless we need it.

@hkeebler I had this old branch to do this back when I created the new accumulo-proxy repo, but never merged it. Since you're working on getting the new repository up-to-speed in apache/accumulo-proxy#3, I figured I'd go ahead and push my changes to do what's needed on this side of things. Let me know if you have any questions.

@hkeebler Sorry for the confusion. There are two pieces to the move:

1. (this PR) delete the proxy from apache/accumulo
2. (apache/accumulo-proxy#3) ensure the code at the destination is updated to reflect the changes here (prior to it being deleted) and that it builds and functions as a proxy.

If necessary, feel free to close apache/accumulo-proxy#3 and split any remaining tasks into smaller tickets and/or pull requests, since that original ticket was kind of a catch-all for all of it and may not reflect the current outstanding tasks any longer (especially after this PR is merged, which deletes the proxy from here).
